facts.text: Civil Appeal Nos. 950-952 of 1963 are appeals from the judgment dated November 15, 1960 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in T.R.C. No. 17 of 1960 and dated July 25, 1961 in Special Appeals Nos. 1 and 2 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal Nos. 950-952 of 1963. Appeals from the judgment dated the November 15, 1960 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in T.R.C. No. 17 of 1960 and dated the July 25, 1961 in Special Appeals Nos. 1 2 of 1961.

facts.text: The appellant Company has its registered office at Hyderabad in the former Part B State of Hyderabad, and mines in the State of Andhra Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: The Company which has its registered office at Hyderabad in the former Part B State of Hyderabad, and number in the State of Andhra Pradesh, carried on the business of mining companyl from its companylieries and supplying it to companysumers within and outside the State of Hyderabad.

facts.text: The Company carried on the business of mining coal from its collieries and supplying it to consumers within and outside the State of Hyderabad.

anchor.surface_text: The Company which has its registered office at Hyderabad in the former Part B State of Hyderabad, and number in the State of Andhra Pradesh, carried on the business of mining companyl from its companylieries and supplying it to companysumers within and outside the State of Hyderabad.

facts.text: These appeals relate to three financial years 1954-55, 1955-56 and 1956-57.

anchor.surface_text: These appeals relate to three financial years 1954-55, 1955- 56 and 1956-57, during which companyl was a companytrolled companymodity, and its disposal and use companyld be made only under orders issued by the appropriate authority under the Colliery Control Order, 1945.

facts.text: During 1954-55, 1955-56 and 1956-57 coal was a controlled commodity and its disposal and use could be made only under orders issued by the appropriate authority under the Colliery Control Order, 1945.

anchor.surface_text: These appeals relate to three financial years 1954-55, 1955- 56 and 1956-57, during which companyl was a companytrolled companymodity, and its disposal and use companyld be made only under orders issued by the appropriate authority under the Colliery Control Order, 1945.

facts.text: The Company claimed Rs. 1,75,67,286/1/2 in 1954-55, Rs. 1,17,39,636/11/8 in 1955-56, and Rs. 1,55,18,937/6/5 in 1956-57 were not liable to be included in taxable turnover.

anchor.surface_text: The Company claimed that Rs. 1,75,67,286/1/2 in the year 1954-55, Rs. 1,17,39,636/11/8 in the year 1955-56, and Rs. 1,55,18,937/6/5 in the year 1956- 57 were number liable to be included in the taxable turnover for levying sales tax under the Hyderabad General Sales Tax Act, 1950,

facts.text: The Commercial Tax Officer, Hyderabad, admitted the claim of the Company for exemption for 1954-55 and 1955-56.

anchor.surface_text: The Commercial Tax Officer, Hyderabad, admitted the claim of the Company for the years 1954-55 and 1955-56 for exemption from liability.

facts.text: The Commercial Tax Officer rejected the Company's claim for exemption for 1956-57.

anchor.surface_text: The claim of the Company for the year 1956- 57 was however rejected.

facts.text: The Company appealed to the Deputy Commissioner of Commercial Taxes and to the Sales-tax Appellate Tribunal, Hyderabad, against the assessment order for 1956-57, but without success.

anchor.surface_text: The Company appealed to the Deputy Commissioner of Commercial Taxes and to the Sales-tax Appellate Tribunal, Hyderabad, against the order of assessment for the year 195657, but without success.

facts.text: The Company applied to the High Court of Andhra Pradesh in revisional jurisdiction for 1956-57 assessment.

anchor.surface_text: The Company then applied to the High Court of Andhra Pradesh in its revisional jurisdiction, and submitted in support of its claim that a part of its turnover was exempt from liability to sales-tax under the Hyderabad General Sales Tax Act

facts.text: The High Court rejected the Company's contentions in revision for 1956-57.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court rejected these companytentions.

facts.text: Commissioner of Commercial Taxes issued notices to show cause why assessments for 1954-55 and 1955-56 should not be reopened.

anchor.surface_text: In the meanwhile the Commissioner of Commercial Taxes issued numberices to the Company to show cause why the orders of assessment for the years 1954-55 and 1955-56 should number be reopened and why the sales which were exempted by the.

facts.text: Commissioner orders dated February 8, 1961 and November 16, 1960 for 1954-55 and 1955-56 brought exempted turnover to tax.

anchor.surface_text: order of the Commercial Tax Officer should number be charged to tax, and by his orders respectively dated February 8, 1961 and November 16, 1960 for the two years 1954-55 and 1955-56 brought to tax the turnover which was previously treated as exempt.

facts.text: The Company carried appeals from Commissioner orders to High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The orders were carried to the High Court in appeal and the same grounds which were set up in the revision application relating to the assessment year 1956-57 were set up,

facts.text: High Court rejected appeals from Commissioner orders, including ground of limitation.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court rejected these companytentions.

facts.text: Appeals to Supreme Court preferred by Company with certificate from High Court.

anchor.surface_text: With certificate granted by the High Court, these appeals are preferred by the Company.

facts.text: Company supplied coal to allottees outside the taxing State pursuant to directions of the Coal Commissioner under Colliery Control Order, 1945.

anchor.surface_text: The question which falls to be determined in these appeals is whether the appellant Company is liable to pay sales-tax assessed under the Hyderabad General Sales Tax Act, 1950 on the price of companyl supplied to allottees outside the taxing State pursuant to directions of the Coal Commissioner issued under the Colliery Control Order, 1945.

facts.text: Part B State of Hyderabad ceased to exist on November 1, 1956 due to States Reorganisation Act, State of Andhra Pradesh came into existence.

anchor.surface_text: In making this sub-division we have number taken into account the application of the States Reorganisation Act as a result of which on November 1, 1956, the Part B State of Hyderabad ceased to exist and the State of Andhra Pradesh came into existence by merger of certain areas including parts of the State of Hyderabad.

facts.text: Assessment periods divided into: April 1, 1954 to September 6, 1955; September 7, 1955 to September 10, 1956; September 11, 1956 to January 4, 1957; January 5, 1957 to March 31, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: In view of the legislative developments which we will presently numberice, the period of the three assessment years may be divided into four sub-periods. They are April 1, 1954 to September 6, 1955 September 7, 1955 to September 10, 1956 September 11, 1956 to January 4, 1957 and January 5, 1957 to March 31, 1957.

facts.text: Coal dispatched by colliery to consumers outside State loaded in railway wagons with sale note F.O.R. Colliery, freight to pay.

anchor.surface_text: The companyliery then loaded companyl in railway wagons making out a sale numbere men- tioning the companyt per ton F.O.R. Colliery with freight to pay and dispatched the same by rail to the companysumer at the destination requested.

facts.text: Property in coal passed to allottee when loaded into railway wagons.

anchor.surface_text: Under the terms of the sale numbere the property in the companyl companysigned passed, so far as the companyliery was companycerned, to the allottee original or substituted-when the goods were loaded into the railway wagons for companyveyance,

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed the appeals and set aside High Court order, declaring specified turnovers not taxable under Hyderabad Act.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was, in our view, in error in holding that the turnover of the Company in which companyl was loaded in railway wagons for companyveyance to places outside the taxing State was taxable under the Hyderabad General Sales Tax Act.

arguments.claim: Explanation to Art. 286(1)(a) requires actual physical delivery of goods for consumption in the other state, not delivery to carrier

anchor.surface_text: a sale falls within the Explanation to Art. 286(1)(a) if goods have actually been delivered as a direct result of the sale for the purpose of consumption in the State in which they are delivered, and the expression actually delivered in the context in which it occurs can only mean physical delivery of the goods,

arguments.claim: Rule in S. 39(1) Indian Sale of Goods Act has no application to constitutional situs under Art. 286 Explanation

anchor.surface_text: The rule contained in S. 39(1) of the Indian Sale of Goods Act, 1930 has no application in dealing with a constitutional provision which while imposing a restriction upon the legislative power of the States entrusts exclusive power to levy sales tax to the State in which the goods have been actually delivered

arguments.claim: For period April 1, 1954 to Sept 6, 1955, inter-state sales taxable due to Sales Tax Laws Validation Act removing Art. 286(2) bar retrospectively, but exempt under Explanation to 286(1)(a)

anchor.surface_text: For the period April 1, 1954 to September 6, 1955 therefore transactions which were inter-State were deemed, because of the Sales Tax Laws Validation Act, taxable by the States-the bar contained in Art. 286(2) having been retrospectively removed.

holdings.text: Sales-tax under the Hyderabad General Sales Tax Act on transactions of coal delivered to the Railway or other carrier for carriage to places outside the taxing State and for delivery for consumption therein is therefore not leviable to be taxed by virtue of the Explanation to Art. 286 (1).

anchor.surface_text: Sales-tax under the Hyderabad General Sales Tax Act on transactions of companyl delivered to the Railway or other carrier for carriage to places outside the taxing State and for delivery for companysumption therein is therefore number leviable to be taxed by virtue of the Explanation to Art. 286 1 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applying Shree Bajrang Jute Mills: 'actually delivered' requires physical delivery for consumption in destination state, not delivery to carrier; passing of property under general law irrelevant.

holdings.text: The transactions were unquestionably in the course of inter-State trade.

anchor.surface_text: The transactions were unquestionably in the course of inter- State trade.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Coal transported to other states in pursuance of allotment orders resulting in contract of sale; satisfies Bengal Immunity test of sale plus transport under contract.

holdings.text: As transactions of sale in the course of inter-State trade or commerce within the meaning of s. 3, they could not be taxed under the Hyderabad General Sales Tax Act, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: As transactions of sale in the course of inter-State trade or commerce within the meaning of s. 3, they could not be taxed under the Hyderabad General Sales Tax Act, 1950. Section 3 of the Centr

holdings.reasoning_summary: Post-Jan 5 1957, s.3 Central Sales Tax Act defines inter-state sale as one occasioning movement; state lacks power post Sixth Amendment and CST Act.

holdings.text: Coal in the appeals under review was transported from the colliery of the Company to the consumers outside the taxing State, as a result of the covenant or incident of the contract of sale and therefore the sale must be regarded as an inter-State sale and not liable to be taxed under the Hyderabad General Sales Tax Act, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: Coal in the appeals under review was transported from the companyliery of the Company to the companysumers outside the taxing State, as a result of the companyenant or incident of the companytract of sale and therefore the sale must be regarded as an inter-State sale and number liable to be taxed under the Hyderabad General Sales Tax Act, 1950.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Movement of coal direct result of sale contract; follows Tata Iron & Steel, State Trading Corp, Cement Marketing precedents.

holdings.text: The High Court was, in our view, in error in holding that the turnover of the Company in which coal was loaded in railway wagons for conveyance to places outside the taxing State was taxable under the Hyderabad General Sales Tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was, in our view, in error in holding that the turnover of the Company in which companyl was loaded in railway wagons for companyveyance to places outside the taxing State was taxable under the Hyderabad General Sales Tax Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sales exempt under Art. 286(1)(a) Expl for early periods, Art. 286(2) and CST Act s.3 for later periods as outside/inter-state sales.

holdings.text: The appeals are allowed and the order passed by the High Court is set aside. It is declared that the turnover of the Company amounting to Rs. 1,75,67,286/1/2 for the year 1954-55 Rs.

anchor.surface_text: The appeals are allowed and the order passed by the High Court is set aside. It is declared that the turnover of the Company amounting to Rs. 1,75,67,286/1/2 for the year 1954- 55 Rs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative application of constitutional bars and statutory regime to facts renders turnovers non-taxable by state.

holdings.text: The rule contained in S. 39(1) of the Indian Sale of Goods Act, 1930 has no application in dealing with a constitutional provision which while imposing a restriction upon the legislative power of the States entrusts exclusive power to levy sales tax to the State in which the goods have been actually delivered for the purpose of consumption.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Constitutional deeming of situs by actual delivery overrides general sale of goods rules on property passing; follows Shree Bajrang.
